list.title: Question 1
list.content:
The diagram below shows a straight line $L_1$ which passes through
A$(0,-2)$ and B$(8,0)$.
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/47b65cc9-515d-4eb0-ae20-be61fd47f030/images/e476ece8-ad04-4e3b-8740-1be6a35203d6/dd225af0bca38352f0853ac9a9eb9c1cd3829f36.svg)



- Write down the coordinates of the midpoint of line segment [AB].
[2]


Another line, $L_2$ , intersects the $y$-axis at
C$(0,3)$ and is parallel to $L_1$.

- Find the gradient of $L_2$. [2]

- Find the equation of $L_2$, giving your answer in the form
$y = mx+c$. [2]
list.markScheme:
- $\answer{(4,-1)}$
- The gradient of $L_2$ is

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{12.2em} m_{L_2} &= m_{L_1}  \hspace{3em} [\text{since $L_2 \parallel L_1$}] \\[6pt]
  &= \dfrac{0-(-2)}{8-0} \hspace{3em} [\text{by gradient formula}] \\[8pt]
  &\answer{= 0.25}\end{aligned}
  $$

- Using the point-gradient formula with C$(0,3)$ and $m = 0.25$, we
get

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  y - y_1 &= m(x - x_1) \\[6pt]
  y - 3 &= 0.25\hspace{0.05em}(x-0) \\
  \end{aligned}
  $$


  $$
  \hspace{1.3em} \answer{y = 0.25x + 3}
  $$

list.title: Question 2
list.content:
A small town is planning the construction of a new road. The new road will pass through the point A$(0,5)$ and will be perpendicular to the road connecting the points B$(3,0)$ and C$(6,6)$. This information is shown in the following diagram.
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/b30beb64-0ecd-4246-8108-6275a6e4a3b6/images/8ae74cd9-ad4b-4f19-bde8-a50bf3a19b39/55d55a043dfcb136022e8a71a28efdbe577c0832.svg)



- Find the gradient of the line through points B and C. [2]

- Hence, state the gradient of the line through points A and D. [1]

- Find the equation of the line through A and D. Give your answer in the form $y=mx+c$.[2]

- Point D lies on the $x$-axis. Find the coordinates of point D.[2]
list.markScheme:
- Using the gradient formula, we get

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  m_{\mathrm{BC}} &= \dfrac{6-0}{6-3} \\[12pt]
  &\hspace{-2.2em}\tcbhighmath{m_{\mathrm{BC}} = 2}\end{aligned}
  $$

- Since A and D lie on a perpendicular line to the line through B and
C we get

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  m_{\mathrm{AD}} &= -\dfrac{1}{m_{\mathrm{BC}}} \\[12pt]
  &\hspace{-2.25em}\tcbhighmath{ m_{\mathrm{AD}} = -\dfrac{1}{2}}\end{aligned}
  $$

- The $y$-intercept of the line through points A and D is $(0,5)$, therefore we have $c = 5$. Using the gradient-intercept formula with $c = 5$ and $m=-\dfrac{1}{2}$, we get
$m=-\dfrac{1}{2}$, we get

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  &\hspace{-0.5em}\tcbhighmath{y = -\dfrac{1}{2}x + 5}\end{aligned}
  $$

- As point D lies on the $x$-axis, it has a $y$-coordinate of $0$. Using the solution from part (c)  and substituting in $y = 0$, we have

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  0 &= -\dfrac{1}{2}x + 5 \\[12pt]
  \dfrac{1}{2}x &= 5 \\[12pt]
  x &= 10\end{aligned}
  $$

  Therefore, point D has coordinates
$\answer{(10,0)}$

list.title: Question 3
list.content:
The diagram shows the straight line $L_1$, which intersects the $x$-axis
at A$(-8,0)$ and the $y$-axis at B$(0,4)$.
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/4b3e7801-0e33-489b-9a1d-49c48847723a/images/d9f6f8fd-c35c-40a4-938d-58f9cb89eef1/c40083b445b05ffe171f553a310158b5de8ce983.svg)



- Write down the coordinates of M, the midpoint of line segment
[AB].[2]

- Calculate the gradient of $L_1$. [2]


The line $L_2$ is perpendicular to $L_1$ and passes through the point
P$(1,2)$.

- Find the equation of $L_2$. Give your answer in the form
$y = mx + c$.   [2]
list.markScheme:
- M:  $\answer{(-4,2)}$
- The gradient of $L_1$ is

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{11.9em} m_{L_1} &= \dfrac{4-0}{0-(-8)} \hspace{3em} [\text{by gradient formula}] \\[8pt]
  &\answer{= 0.5}\end{aligned}
  $$

- The gradient of $L_2$ is

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{8.1em} m_{L_2} &= -\dfrac{1}{m_{L_1}} \hspace{3em} [\text{since $L_2 \perp L_1$}] \\[5pt]
  &= -\dfrac{1}{0.5} \\[12pt]
  &= -2\end{aligned}
  $$

  Hence, using the point-gradient formula with
P$(1,2)$ and $m = -2$, we get

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  y - y_1 &= m(x - x_1) \hspace{0.7em} \\[6pt]
  y - 2 &= -2\hspace{0.05em}(x-1) \\[6pt]
  y - 2 &= -2x + 2 \\
  \end{aligned}
  $$


  $$
  \hspace{0.5em} \answer{y = -2x + 4}
  $$

list.title: Question 4
list.content:
The straight line, $L_1$, has the equation $y = \dfrac{1}{3}x-5$.

- Write down the $y$-intercept of $L_1$. [1]

- Write down the gradient of $L_1$. [1]


The line $L_2$ is perpendicular to $L_1$ and passes through the point
A$(2,4)$.

- Find the gradient of $L_2$. [1]

- Find the equation of $L_2$, giving your answer in the form
$ax + by + d = 0$,
where $a,b,d \in \mathbb{Z}$. [3]
list.markScheme:
- $\answer{\mathrm{B}(0,-5)}$
- $\answer{m_{L_1} = 1/3}$
- The gradient of $L_2$ is

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{8.8em} m_{L_2} &= -\dfrac{1}{m_{L_1}} \hspace{3em} [\text{since $L_2 \perp L_1$}] \\[6pt]
  &= -\dfrac{1}{1/3} \\[10pt]
  &\answer{= -3}\end{aligned}
  $$

- Using the point-gradient formula with A$(2,4)$ and $m = -3$, we find

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  y - y_1 &= m(x - x_1) \\[6pt]
  y - 4 &= -3(x-2) \\[6pt]
  y - 4 &= -3x+6 \\
  \end{aligned}
  $$


  $$
  \answer{3x + y - 10 = 0} \hspace{6.3em}
  $$

list.title: Question 5
list.content:
The equation of a line $L_1$ is $y = 0.5x + p$. The point A$(2,-1)$ lies
on $L_1$.

- Find the value of $p$. [2]


A second line, $L_2$ , is perpendicular to $L_1$
and intersects $L_1$ at point A.

- Find the gradient of $L_2$. [1]

- Find the equation of $L_2$. Give your answer in the form
$y = mx+c$. [2]

- Write your answer to part (c) in the form
$ax + by + d = 0$, where $a, b, d \in \mathbb{Z}$.[1]
list.markScheme:
- Substituting $x = 2$ and $y = -1$ in the equation of $L_1$, we get

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{2.2em}  -1 = 0.5(2) + p \\
  \end{aligned}
  $$


  $$
  \answer{p = -2}
  $$

- The gradient of $L_2$ is

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{9.8em} m_{L_2} &= -\dfrac{1}{m_{L_1}} \hspace{3em} [\text{since $L_2 \perp L_1$}] \\[6pt]
  &= -\dfrac{1}{0.5} \\[12pt]
  &\answer{= -2}\end{aligned}
  $$

- Using the point-gradient formula with A$(2,-1)$ and $m = -2$, we
obtain

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  y - y_1 &= m(x - x_1) \\[6pt]
  y - (-1) &= -2\hspace{0.05em}(x-2) \hspace{0.25em} \\
  \end{aligned}
  $$


  $$
  \hspace{2.2em} \answer{y = -2x + 3}
  $$

- $\answer{2x + y - 3 = 0}$

list.title: Question 6
list.content:
The equation of a line $L_1$ is $y - 3x + 5 = 0$.

- For the line $L_1$, find:
  
  - the $x$-intercept;
  - the gradient. [2]



A second line, $L_2$, intersects the $y$-axis at P$(0,2)$ and is
parallel to $L_1$.

- Find the equation of $L_2$. Give your answer in the form
$y = mx+c$. [1]


A third line, $L_3$, passes through the point Q$(3,1)$ and is
perpendicular to $L_1$.

- Find the gradient of the line $L_3$. [1]

- Find the equation of $L_3$, giving your answer in the form
$ax + by + d = 0$,
where $a, b, d \in \mathbb{Z}$.[2]
list.markScheme:
- 
  - Substituting $y = 0$ in the equation of $L_1$, we have

    $$
    \begin{aligned}
    0 - 3x + 5 &= 0 \hspace{2.3em} \\[9pt]
    5 &= 3x \\[4pt]
    x &= \dfrac{5}{3}\end{aligned}
    $$

    Hence the point
$\answer{\text{A}(5/3,0)}$
is the $x$-intercept of $L_1$.
  - If we rewrite the equation of $L_1$ in the form $y = mx + c$, we
have

    $$
    \begin{aligned}
    y - 3x + 5 &= 0 \\[6pt]
    y &= 3x - 5 \end{aligned}
    $$

    Hence the gradient of $L_1$ is
$\answer{m_{L_1} = 3}$

- The gradient of $L_2$ is

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{6.9em} m_{L_2} &= m_{L_1} \hspace{3em} [\text{since $L_2 \parallel L_1$}] \\[6pt]
  &= 3\end{aligned}
  $$

  Hence, using the point-gradient formula with
P$(0,2)$ and $m = 3$, we get

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  y - y_1 &= m(x - x_1) \hspace{0.6em} \\[6pt]
  y - 2 &= 3\hspace{0.05em}(x-0) \\
  \end{aligned}
  $$


  $$
  \answer{y = 3x + 2} \hspace{0.1em}
  $$

- The gradient of $L_3$ is

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{8.2em} m_{L_3} &= -\dfrac{1}{m_{L_1}} \hspace{3em} [\text{since $L_3 \perp L_1$}] \\[6pt]
  &\answer{= -\dfrac{1}{3}}\end{aligned}
  $$

- Using the point-gradient formula with Q$(3,1)$ and $m = -1/3$, we
obtain

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  y - y_1 &= m(x - x_1) \hspace{0.7em} \\[6pt]
  y - 1 &= -\dfrac{1}{3}\hspace{0.05em}(x-3) \\[8pt]
  3y - 3 &= -x + 3 \\
  \end{aligned}
  $$


  $$
  \answer{x + 3y - 6 = 0} \hspace{6.5em}
  $$

list.title: Question 7
list.content:
The coordinates of point K are $(-2,-3)$ and the coordinates of point N
are $(8,6)$. M is the midpoint of [KN].

- Find the coordinates of M. [2]  

$L_1$ is the line which passes through K and N.

- Find the gradient of $L_1$.   [2]  

A new line, $L_2$, is perpendicular to $L_1$ and passes through M.

- 
  - Write down the gradient of $L_2$.
  - Write down the equation of $L_2$ in the form $y = mx + c$.
[3]
list.markScheme:
- Using the coordinates of a midpoint formula, we get

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \text M &= \left(\dfrac {x_1+x_2} 2, \dfrac {y_1 + y_2} 2\right)\rule[-4mm]{0pt}{3mm}\\
  & = \left(\dfrac {-2 + 8} 2, \dfrac {-3 + 6} 2\right)\rule[-4mm]{0pt}{10mm}\\
  &\answer{  = \left(3, \dfrac 3 2\right)}   \rule[0mm]{0pt}{6mm}\end{aligned}
  $$

- Using the gradient formula, we obtain

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  m_{L_1} &=  \dfrac {y_2 - y_1} {x_2 - x_1}\rule[-3.5mm]{0pt}{4mm}\\
  & = \dfrac {6 - (-3)}{8 - (-2)}\rule[-3.5mm]{0pt}{9mm}\\
  &\answer{  = \dfrac {9} {10}}\rule[0mm]{0pt}{5.5mm}\\
  \end{aligned}
  $$

- 
  - Since $L_2$ is perpendicular to $L_1$, then

    $$
    \begin{aligned}
    m_{L_2} & = -\dfrac 1 {m_{L_1}}\hspace{5mm}\\[6pt]
    &\answer{  = -\dfrac {10}{9}}\\
    \end{aligned}
    $$

  - From (c) (i) we have $y = -\dfrac {10}{9} \,x + c$. To find $c$
we substitute the coordinates of M into the equation (since
$L_2$ passes through M).

    $$
    \begin{aligned}
    \dfrac 3 2  & = -\dfrac {10} {9} \left(3 \right) + c\rule[-3.5mm]{0pt}{4mm}\\
    \dfrac 3 2  & = -\dfrac {10}{3} + c\rule[-3.5mm]{0pt}{9mm}\\
    c & = \dfrac 3 2 + \dfrac {10} {3}\rule[-3.5mm]{0pt}{9mm}\\
    c & = \dfrac {29}{6}\rule[0mm]{0pt}{5.5mm}\\
    \end{aligned}
    $$

    Hence the equation of $L_2$ is

    $$
    \begin{aligned}
    &\answer{ y = -\dfrac {10} {9}\, x + \dfrac {29}{6}}\end{aligned}
    $$

list.title: Question 8
list.content:
The coordinates of point P are $(-4,6)$ and the coordinates of point Q
are $(5,1)$. M is the midpoint of [PQ].

- Find the coordinates of M. [2]  

$L_1$ is the line which passes through P and Q.

- Find the gradient of $L_1$.   [2]  

A new line, $L_2$, is perpendicular to $L_1$ and passes through M.

- 
  - Write down the gradient of $L_2$.
  - Write down the equation of $L_2$ in the form $y = mx + c$.
[3]
list.markScheme:
- Using the coordinates of a midpoint formula, we get

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \text M &= \left(\dfrac {x_1+x_2} 2, \dfrac {y_1 + y_2} 2\right)\rule[-4mm]{0pt}{10mm}\\
  & = \left(\dfrac {-4+5} 2, \dfrac {6+1} 2\right)\rule[-4mm]{0pt}{10mm}\\
  &\answer{  = \left(\dfrac 1 2, \dfrac 7 2\right)}\rule[-4mm]{0pt}{10mm}    \end{aligned}
  $$

- Using the gradient formula, we obtain

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  m_{L_1} &= \dfrac {y_2 - y_1} {x_2 - x_1} \rule[-4mm]{0pt}{0mm}\\
  & = \dfrac {1 - 6}{5-(-4)} \rule[-4mm]{0pt}{10mm}\\
  &\answer{  = -\dfrac 5 9}\rule[0mm]{0pt}{6mm}\\
  \end{aligned}
  $$

- 
  - Since $L_2$ is perpendicular to $L_1$, then

    $$
    \begin{aligned}
    m_{L_2}     & = -\dfrac 1 {m_{L_1}}\hspace{5mm}\\[6pt]
    &\answer{  = \dfrac 9 5}\\
    \end{aligned}
    $$

  - From (c) (i) we have $y = \dfrac 9 5 \,x + c$. To find $c$ we
substitute the coordinates of M into the equation (since $L_2$
passes through M).

    $$
    \begin{aligned}
    \dfrac 7 2  & = \dfrac 9 5 \left(\dfrac 1 2 \right) + c\rule[-3.5mm]{0pt}{9mm}\\
    \dfrac 7 2  & = \dfrac {9}{10} + c\rule[-3.5mm]{0pt}{9mm}\\
    c       & = \dfrac 7 2 - \dfrac 9 {10}\rule[-3.5mm]{0pt}{9mm}\\
    c       & = \dfrac {13}{5}\rule[-3.5mm]{0pt}{9mm}\\
    \end{aligned}
    $$

    Hence the equation of $L_2$ is

    $$
    \begin{aligned}
    &\answer{ y = \dfrac 9 5\, x + \dfrac {13}{5}}\end{aligned}
    $$

list.title: Question 9
list.content:
The equation of a line $L_1$ is $2x + 3y = -5$.

- Find the gradient of $L_1$. [1]


A second line, $L_2$, is perpendicular to $L_1$.

- Find the gradient of $L_2$. [1]


The point P$(4,0)$ lies on $L_2$.

- Find the equation of $L_2$, giving your answer in the form
$ax + by + d = 0$, where $a, b, d \in \mathbb{Z}$. [2]


The point Q is the intersection of $L_1$ and $L_2$.

- Find the coordinates of Q. [2]
list.markScheme:
- If we rewrite the equation of $L_1$ in the form $y = mx + c$, we
have

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  2x + 3y &= -5 \\[12pt]
  3y &= -2x - 5 \\[6pt]
  y &= -\dfrac{2}{3}x-\dfrac{5}{3} \hspace{0.4em} \\
  \end{aligned}
  $$

  Hence the gradient of $L_1$ is
$\answer{m_{L_1} = -2/3}$
- The gradient of $L_2$ is

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{9em} m_{L_2} &= -\dfrac{1}{m_{L_1}} \hspace{3em} [\text{since $L_2 \perp L_1$}] \\[6pt]
  &= -\dfrac{1}{(-2/3)} \\[6pt]
  &\answer{= \dfrac{3}{2}}\end{aligned}
  $$

- Using the point-gradient formula with P$(4,0)$ and $m = 3/2$, we get

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{0.2em} y - y_1 &= m(x - x_1) \\[5pt]
  y - 0 &= \dfrac{3}{2}\hspace{0.05em}(x - 4) \\[6pt]
  2y &= 3x - 12 \\
  \end{aligned}
  $$


  $$
  \hspace{3.45em} \answer{0 = 3x - 2y - 12}
  $$

- We have

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  L_1&:\hspace{1.0em} 2x + 3y = -5 \qref{(1)} \\[6pt]
  L_2&:\hspace{1.0em} 3x - 2y = 12 \qref{(2)}\end{aligned}
  $$

  Solving
the system of linear equations $(1)$-$(2)$ for $x$ and $y$, we
obtain

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  
  \hspace{10.8em} \begin{array}{rcl}
  x &=& 2 \\[6pt]
  y &=& -3
  \end{array} \hspace{4em} [\text{by using G.D.C.}]\end{aligned}
  $$

  Hence the coordinates of Q are
$\answer{(2,-3)}$

list.title: Question 10
list.content:
The coordinates of point A are $(-1,-7)$ and the coordinates of point
$B$ are $(5,2)$. $L_1$ is the line which passes through A and B.

- Find the equation of $L_1$.   [3]  

Point M is the midpoint of [AB]. The line $L_2$ is perpendicular to
$L_1$ and passes through M.

- Find the equation of $L_2$.   [3]
list.markScheme:
- First, let's find the gradient of $L_1$. Using the gradient formula,
we obtain

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  m_{L_1} &= \dfrac {y_2 - y_1} {x_2 - x_1}\rule[-3.5mm]{0pt}{3mm}\\
  & = \dfrac {2 - (-7)}{5 - (-1)} \rule[-3.7mm]{0pt}{8mm}\\
  &  = \dfrac{9}{6} \rule[-3.5mm]{0pt}{8mm}\\
  & = \dfrac 3 2 \rule[0mm]{0pt}{4.5mm}\end{aligned}
  $$

  So far the
equation of $L_1$ is $y = \dfrac 3 2 \, x + c$. To find $c$ we can
substitute in the coordinates of B into the equation

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  2   & = \dfrac 3 2 \,(5) + c\\[6pt]
  c   & = -\dfrac {11} 2\end{aligned}
  $$

  Hence the equation of $L_1$ is

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  &\answer{ y    = \dfrac 3 2 \,x - \dfrac {11} 2}\end{aligned}
  $$

- Since $L_2$ is perpendicular to $L_1$, then

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  m_{L_2}     & = -\dfrac 1 {m_{L_1}}\hspace{5mm}\\
  & = -\dfrac 2 3 \end{aligned}
  $$

  So far we have
$y = -\dfrac 2 3\, x + c$.
  Let's find coordinates of M. Using the coordinates of a midpoint
formula, we get

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \text M &= \left(\dfrac {x_1+x_2} 2, \dfrac {y_1 + y_2} 2\right)\rule[-4mm]{0pt}{3mm}\\
  & = \left(\dfrac {-1 + 5} 2, \dfrac {-7 + 2} 2\right)\rule[-4mm]{0pt}{9mm}\\
  &\answer{  = \left(2, -\dfrac 5 2\right)}\rule[0mm]{0pt}{6mm}  \end{aligned}
  $$

  To find $c$ we can substitute M into the equation (since $L_2$
passes through M).

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  -\dfrac 5 2 & = -\dfrac 2 3  (2) + c\rule[-3mm]{0pt}{3mm}\\
  c   & = -\dfrac 5 2 + \dfrac 4 3\rule[-3mm]{0pt}{8mm}\\
  c   & = -\dfrac 7 6\rule[0mm]{0pt}{5mm}\end{aligned}
  $$

  Hence the
equation of $L_2$ is

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  &\answer{ y = -\dfrac 2 3  x - \dfrac 7 6}\end{aligned}
  $$

list.title: Question 11
list.content:
The coordinates of point A are $(6,-3)$ and the coordinates of point B
are $(-2,-1)$. $L_1$ is the line which passes through A and B.

- Find the equation of $L_1$.   [3]  

Point M is the midpoint of [AB]. The line $L_2$ is perpendicular to
$L_1$ and passes through M.

- Find the equation of $L_2$.   [3]
list.markScheme:
- First, let's find the gradient of $L_1$. Using the gradient formula,
we obtain

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  m_{L_1} &= \dfrac {y_2 - y_1} {x_2 - x_1}\rule[-3.5mm]{0pt}{3mm}\\
  & = \dfrac {-1 - (-3)}{-2 - 6} \rule[-3.5mm]{0pt}{9mm}\\
  &  = \dfrac{2}{-8} \rule[-3.5mm]{0pt}{9mm}\\
  & = -\dfrac 1 4 \rule[0mm]{0pt}{5.5mm}\end{aligned}
  $$

  So far the
equation of $L_1$ is $y = -\dfrac 1 4 \, x + c$. To find $c$ we can
substitute coordinates of B into the equation

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  -1  & = -\dfrac 1 4 (-2) + c\\[6pt]
  c   & = -\dfrac 3 2\end{aligned}
  $$

  Hence the equation of $L_1$
is

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  &\answer{ y    = -\dfrac 1 4 \,x - \dfrac 3 2}\end{aligned}
  $$

- Since $L_2$ is perpendicular to $L_1$, then

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  m_{L_2}     & = -\dfrac 1 {m_{L_1}}\hspace{5mm}\\[6pt]
  & = 4\end{aligned}
  $$

  So far we have $y = 4 x + c$.
  Let's find the coordinates of the midpoint, M. Using the coordinates
of a midpoint formula, we get

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \text M &= \left(\dfrac {x_1+x_2} 2, \dfrac {y_1 + y_2} 2\right)\rule[-3.5mm]{0pt}{3mm}\\
  & = \left(\dfrac {6 - 2} 2, \dfrac {-3 - 1} 2\right)\rule[-3.5mm]{0pt}{9mm}\\
  &\answer{  = \left(2, -2\right)}   \rule[0mm]{0pt}{5.5mm}\end{aligned}
  $$

  To find $c$ we substitute M into the equation (since $L_2$ passes
through M).

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  -2  & = 4  (2) + c\rule[-1.5mm]{0pt}{3mm}\\
  c   & = -2 - 8\rule[-1.5mm]{0pt}{5.5mm}\\
  c   & = -10\rule[0mm]{0pt}{4mm}\end{aligned}
  $$

  Hence the equation of
$L_2$ is

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  &\answer{ y = 4 x - 10}\end{aligned}
  $$

list.title: Question 12
list.content:
The diagram below shows the straight lines $L_1$ and $L_2$.
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/633be528-7eef-4908-9690-cf9b303eb5ba/images/d0523e39-da10-418a-a674-d373c7768ea3/9ee6dfa84eb27bb1c8584bbd4318407cba979047.svg)



- Find:
  
  - the gradient of $L_1$;
  - the equation of $L_1$, giving your answer in the form
$y = mx + c$. [3]



The equation of $L_2$ is $x - 2y = 0$.

- Find the area of the shaded triangle. [3]
list.markScheme:
- 
  - Using the gradient formula with A$(0,6)$ and B$(8,0)$, we get

    $$
    \begin{aligned}
    m_{L_1} &= \dfrac{0-6}{8-0} \hspace{3em} \\[6pt]
    &\answer{= -\dfrac{3}{4}}\end{aligned}
    $$

  - Using the point-gradient formula with A$(0,6)$ and $m = -3/4$,
we find

    $$
    \begin{aligned}
    y - y_1 &= m(x - x_1) \\[10pt]
    y - 6 &= -\dfrac{3}{4}(x-0) \hspace{1.8em} \\
    \end{aligned}
    $$


    $$
    \answer{y = -\dfrac{3}{4}x+6} \hspace{0.4em}
    $$


- Substituting $x = 2y$ in the equation of $L_1$, we have

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{10em} y &= -\dfrac{3}{4}(2y)+6 \\[6pt]
  y &= 2.4 \hspace{3em} [\text{by using G.D.C.}] \\
  \end{aligned}
  $$

  Hence, using the area of a triangle formula with $b = 8$ and
$h = 2.4$, we obtain

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{1.9em} A &= \dfrac{1}{2}(b\times h) \\[6pt]
  &= \dfrac{1}{2}(8)(2.4) \\[10pt]
  &\answer{= 9.6  \text{ units}^2} \end{aligned}
  $$

list.title: Question 13
list.content:
Bruce goes into a car dealership to purchase a new vehicle. The one he
wants to buy costs $\$16\hspace{0.15em}000$, however he doesn't have
that much money in his bank. The salesman offers him a financing option
of a $30$ % deposit followed by $12$ monthly
payments of $\$1150$.

- Find the amount of the deposit. [1]

- Calculate the total cost of the loan under this financing option.
[2]


Bruce's father generously offers him an interest free loan of
$\$16\hspace{0.15em}000$ to buy the car to avoid the expensive loan
repayments. They agree that Bruce will repay the loan by paying his
father $\$\hspace{0.05em}x$ in the first month and $\$\hspace{0.05em}y$
every following month until the $\$16\hspace{0.15em}000$ is repaid.
The total amount Bruce's father receives after $12$ months is $\$5200$.
This can be expressed by the equation $x + 11y = 5200$. The total amount
that Bruce's father receives after $24$ months is
$\$10\hspace{0.15em}600$.

- Write down a second equation involving $x$ and $y$.
[1]

- Determine the value of $x$ and the value of $y$.
[2]

- Calculate the number of months it will take Bruce's father
to receive
the $\$16\hspace{0.15em}000$. [3]


Bruce decides to buy a cheaper car for $\$12\hspace{0.15em}000$ and
invest the remaining $\$4000$. He is considering two investment options
over four years.
Option A: Compound interest at an annual rate of
$6.5$ %.
Option B: Compound interest at a nominal annual rate of
$6$ %, compounded monthly.
Express each answer in part (f) to the nearest dollar.

- Calculate the value of each investment option after four
years.
  
  - Option A.
  - Option B. [5]
list.markScheme:
- The amount of the deposit is

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{1.4em} \mathrm{PV} &= 16\hspace{0.15em}000\times0.3 \\[6pt]
  &\answer{= \$4800}\end{aligned}
  $$

- The total cost of the loan is

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{3.7em} \mathrm{FV} &= 4800 + 1150\times12 \\[6pt]
  &\answer{= \$18\hspace{0.15em}600}\end{aligned}
  $$

- $\answer{x + 23y = 10\hspace{0.15em}600}$
- We have

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  x+11y &= 5200 \qref{(1)} \\[6pt]
  x + 23y &= 10\hspace{0.15em}600 \hspace{3em} \qref{(2)}\end{aligned}
  $$

  Hence, solving the system of linear equations $(1)$ and $(2)$, we
get

  $$
  
  \hspace{8.9em} \begin{array}{rl}
  &\answer{x = 250} \\[6pt]
  &\answer{y = 450}
  \end{array} \hspace{3em} [\text{by using G.D.C.}]
  $$

- We have

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{4.4em} 250 + 450n &= 16\hspace{0.15em}000 \\[8pt]
  n &= 35 \hspace{3em} [\text{by using G.D.C.}] \\
  \end{aligned}
  $$

  Hence it will take Bruce's father
$\answer{36 \text{ months}}$
to receive the $\$16\hspace{0.15em}000$.
- 
  - We have
    ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/109f5bcf-7e24-48da-933e-bf9abe847c29/images/83b5567c-360a-4827-bcf6-7981fa2e12e1/f5c80495cb4b6289d9e252ee117b474ac0267df8.svg)


    Hence, using the compound interest formula, we get

    $$
    \begin{aligned}
    \hspace{4.1em} \mathrm{FV} &= \text{PV}\bigg(1 + \dfrac{r}{100k}\bigg)^{kn} \\[5pt]
    &= 4000\hspace{0.05em}\bigg(1 + \dfrac{6.5}{100\times1}\bigg)^{1\times 4}  \\[12pt]
    &\answer{\approx \$5146}\end{aligned}
    $$

  - We have
    ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/109f5bcf-7e24-48da-933e-bf9abe847c29/images/2a954c17-2361-4029-9e42-e5a49752668c/94b36ff454d13c51eba6ab9f5086d95bd5a04ffa.svg)


    Hence, using the compound interest formula, we obtain

    $$
    \begin{aligned}
    \hspace{5em} \mathrm{FV} &= 4000\bigg(1 + \dfrac{6}{100\times12}\bigg)^{12\times 4} \\[12pt]
    &\answer{\approx \$5082}\end{aligned}
    $$

list.title: Question 14
list.content:
The diagram below shows the triangle ABC. The point C has coordinates
$(9,5)$ and the equation of the line (AB) is $x+4y = 12$.
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/84736b6d-9b3f-4a1d-aaa7-96f1f82c66c6/images/bacc960f-2cef-46d6-bf11-b301716ccd84/3d9c33de7f7eaf861d1fdfed39a4fd8d1cf5d629.svg)



- Find the coordinates of:
  
  - A;
  - B. [2]


- Show that the length of [AB] is $12.4$ correct to three
significant figures.[2]


The point D lies on the line (AB). The line (CD) is perpendicular to the
line (AB).

- Find:
  
  - the gradient of (CD);
  - the equation of (CD). [5]


- Find the coordinates of D. [3]

- Calculate the length of [CD] correct to three significant
figures. [2]

- Calculate the area of triangle ABC. [3]
list.markScheme:
- 
  - Substituting $x = 0$ in the equation of (AB), we have

    $$
    \begin{aligned}
    0+4y &= 12 \hspace{1.65em} \\[6pt]
    y &= 3\end{aligned}
    $$

    Hence the coordinates of A are
$\answer{(0,3)}$
  - Substituting $y = 0$ in the equation of (AB), we have

    $$
    \begin{aligned}
    x+4(0) &= 12 \hspace{2.5em} \\[6pt]
    x &= 12\end{aligned}
    $$

    Hence the coordinates of B are
$\answer{(12,0)}$

- Using the distance b/n two points formula with A$(0,3)$ and
B$(12,0)$, we get

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{3.6em} \mathrm{AB} &= \sqrt{(12-0)^2 + (0-3)^2} \\[6pt]
  &= \sqrt{12^2 + (-3)^2} \\[9pt]
  &\answer{\approx 12.4}\end{aligned}
  $$

- 
  - If we rewrite the equation of (AB) in the form $y = mx + c$, we
have

    $$
    \begin{aligned}
    \hspace{1em} x+4y &= 12 \\[12pt]
    4y &= -x + 12 \\[6pt]
    y &= -\dfrac{1}{4}x + 3\end{aligned}
    $$

    Hence the gradient
of (CD) is

    $$
    \begin{aligned}
    \hspace{10.9em} m_{(\mathrm{CD})} &= -\dfrac{1}{m_{(\mathrm{AB})}} \hspace{3em} [\text{since $(\mathrm{CD}) \perp (\mathrm{AB})$}] \\[6pt]
    &= -\dfrac{1}{(-1/4)} \\[12pt]
    &\answer{= 4}\end{aligned}
    $$

  - Using the point-gradient formula with C$(9,5)$ and $m = 4$, we
find

    $$
    \begin{aligned}
    y - y_1 &= m(x - x_1) \hspace{0.1em} \\[6pt]
    y - 5 &= 4(x - 9) \\[6pt]
    y - 5 &= 4x - 36 \\
    \end{aligned}
    $$


    $$
    \answer{y = 4x - 31} \hspace{0.05em}
    $$


- We have

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  (\mathrm{AB}) &: \hspace{1.0em} x + 4y = 12 \qref{(1)} \\[6pt]
  (\mathrm{CD}) &: \hspace{1.0em} 4x - y = 31 \qref{(2)}\end{aligned}
  $$

  Solving the system of linear equations $(1)$-$(2)$ for $x$ and $y$,
we obtain

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  
  \hspace{12em} \begin{array}{rcl}
  x &=& 8 \\[6pt]
  y &=& 1
  \end{array} \hspace{4em} [\text{by using G.D.C.}]\end{aligned}
  $$

  Hence the coordinates of D are
$\answer{(8,1)}$
- Using the distance b/n two points formula with C$(9,5)$ and
D$(8,1)$, we get

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{3em} \mathrm{CD} &= \sqrt{(8-9)^2 + (1-5)^2} \\[6pt]
  &= \sqrt{(-1)^2 + (-4)^2} \\[9pt]
  &\answer{\approx 4.12}\end{aligned}
  $$

- Using the area of a triangle formula with $b = 12.4$ and $h = 4.12$,
we obtain

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{0.5em} A &= \dfrac{1}{2}(b\times h) \\[6pt]
  &= \dfrac{1}{2}(12.4)(4.12) \\[10pt]
  &= 25.544 \\[13pt]
  &\answer{\approx 25.5 \text{ units}^2} \end{aligned}
  $$

list.title: Question 15
list.content:
The equation of the line $L_1$ is $3y - x - 5 = 0$. The line $L_1$ is
shown on the diagram below.
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/6727684d-5ad2-4628-a91a-56ec3054bbb5/images/11d4345c-1293-4672-a434-88c3f326f964/f4ed7a05bbd56bbe84b8725c56c6d6ec6699d794.svg)


The point K has coordinates $(4,3)$. The point T has coordinates
$(2,-3)$. The point M is the midpoint of [TK].

- Calculate the coordinates of the point M. [2]

- Show that the point K lies on the line $L_1$. [2]

- Calculate the length of [TK]. [2]


The line $L_2$ passes through the point M and is perpendicular to $L_1$.

- Find the gradient of the line $L_2$. [2]

- Find the equation of $L_2$. Give your answer in the form
$ax + by + d = 0$, where $a, b$ and $d$ are integers. [4]


The point N is the intersection of $L_1$ and $L_2$.

- Calculate the coordinates of N. [3]
list.markScheme:
- We have

  $$
  
  \begin{array}{rcccl}
  \dfrac{x_1+x_2}{2} &=& \dfrac{4+2}{2} &=& 3 \\[12pt]
  \dfrac{y_1+y_2}{2} &=& \dfrac{3+(-3)}{2} &=& 0
  \end{array} \hspace{3em}
  $$

  Hence the coordinates of the midpoint of
the line segment [TK] are
$\answer{(3,0)}$
- Substituting $x = 4$ & $y = 3$ in the left hand side of the equation
of $L_1$, we have

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  3(3) - 4 - 5 &= 9 - 4 - 5 \\[6pt]
  &= 0 \end{aligned}
  $$

  Hence the point K lies on the line $L_1$.
- Using the distance b/n two points formula with T$(2,-3)$ and
K$(4,3)$, we get

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{3.6em} \mathrm{TK} &= \sqrt{(4-2)^2 + (3-(-3))^2} \\[6pt]
  &= \sqrt{2^2 + 6^2} \\[9pt]
  &\answer{\approx 6.32}\end{aligned}
  $$

- If we rewrite the equation of $L_1$ in the form $y = mx + c$, we
have

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  3y - x - 5 &= 0 \hspace{5.2em} \\[12pt]
  3y &= x + 5 \\[6pt]
  y &= \dfrac{1}{3}x + \dfrac{5}{3} \end{aligned}
  $$

  Hence the gradient
of $L_1$ is

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  m_{L_1} &= \dfrac{1}{3} \hspace{2.3em}\end{aligned}
  $$

  Therefore the
gradient of $L_2$ is

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{9.5em} m_{L_2} &= -\dfrac{1}{m_{L_1}} \hspace{3em} [\text{since $L_2 \perp L_1$}] \\[6pt]
  &= -\dfrac{1}{1/3} \\[12pt]
  &\answer{= -3}\end{aligned}
  $$

- Using the point-gradient formula with M$(3,0)$ and $m = -3$, we find

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  y - y_1 &= m(x - x_1) \\[6pt]
  y - 0 &= -3\hspace{0.05em}(x-3) \\[6pt]
  \hspace{2.8em} y &= -3x + 9 \\
  \end{aligned}
  $$


  $$
  \answer{3x + y - 9 = 0} \hspace{5.2em}
  $$

- We have

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  L_1&:\hspace{1.0em} 3y - x = 5 \qref{(1)} \\[6pt]
  L_2&:\hspace{1.0em} 3x + y = 9 \qref{(2)}\end{aligned}
  $$

  Solving the
system of linear equations $(1)$-$(2)$ for $x$ and $y$, we obtain

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  
  \hspace{11em} \begin{array}{rcl}
  x &=& 2.2 \\[6pt]
  y &=& 2.4
  \end{array} \hspace{4em} [\text{by using G.D.C.}]\end{aligned}
  $$

  Hence the coordinates of N are
$\answer{(2.2,2.4)}$

list.title: Question 16
list.content:
The line $L_1$ has equation $2y - x - 10 = 0$ and is shown on the
diagram.
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/b013bdd6-5c84-45cd-88f4-56ef7bb231a9/images/a9ab7183-1dd3-46b7-a00f-eb986d2c8406/de606d5be573f475a578c89b32ed5f6e2d4e6f74.svg)


The point A has coordinates $(2,6)$.

- Show that A lies on $L_1$. [2]


The point C has coordinates $(8,18)$. M is the midpoint of [AC].

- Find the coordinates of M. [2]

- Find the length of [AC]. [2]


The straight line, $L_2$, is perpendicular to [AC] and passes through
M.

- Show that the equation of $L_2$ is $2y + x - 29 = 0$.
[5]


The point D is the intersection of $L_1$ and $L_2$.

- Find the coordinates of D. [2]


The length of [MD] is $\dfrac{9\sqrt{5}}{4}$.

- Write down the length of [MD] correct to three
significant figures. [1]


The point B is such that ABCD is a rhombus.

- Find the area of ABCD. [3]
list.markScheme:
- Substituting $x = 2$ & $y = 6$ in the left hand side of the equation
of $L_1$, we have

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  2(6) - 2 - 10 &= 12 - 2 - 10 \\[6pt]
  &= 0 \end{aligned}
  $$

  Hence the point A$(2,6)$ lies on the line
$L_1$.
- We have

  $$
  
  \hspace{2.8em} \begin{array}{rcccl}
  \dfrac{x_1+x_2}{2} &=& \dfrac{2+8}{2} &=& 5 \\[12pt]
  \dfrac{y_1+y_2}{2} &=& \dfrac{6+18}{2} &=& 12 \\[3pt]
  \end{array} \vspace{0.5em}
  $$

  Hence the coordinates of M are
$\answer{(5,12)}$
- Using the distance b/n two points formula with A$(2,6)$ and
C$(8,18)$, we find

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{3em} \mathrm{AC} &= \sqrt{(8-2)^2 + (18-6)^2} \\[6pt]
  &= \sqrt{6^2 + 12^2} \\[9pt]
  &\answer{\approx 13.4}\end{aligned}
  $$

- The gradient of line segment AC is

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{12em} m_{\mathrm{AC}} &= \dfrac{18-6}{8-2} \hspace{3em} [\text{by gradient formula}] \\[8pt]
  &\answer{= 2}\end{aligned}
  $$

  Hence the gradient
of $L_2$ is

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{9.7em} m_{L_2} &= -\dfrac{1}{m_{\mathrm{AC}}} \hspace{3em} [\text{since $L_2 \perp L_1$}] \\[6pt]
  &\answer{= -\dfrac{1}{2}} \\
  \end{aligned}
  $$

  Hence, using the point-gradient formula with M$(5,12)$ and
$m = -1/2$, we get

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  y - y_1 &= m(x - x_1) \\[6pt]
  y - 12 &= -\dfrac{1}{2}\hspace{0.05em}(x-5) \\[6pt]
  \hspace{0.3em}  2y - 24 &= -x + 5 \\
  \end{aligned}
  $$


  $$
  \answer{2y + x - 29 = 0} \hspace{5.6em}
  $$

- We have

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  L_1&:\hspace{1.0em} 2y - x = 10 \qref{(1)} \\[6pt]
  L_2&:\hspace{1.0em} 2y + x = 29 \qref{(2)}\end{aligned}
  $$

  Solving
the system of linear equations $(1)$-$(2)$ for $x$ and $y$, we
obtain

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  
  \hspace{11.3em} \begin{array}{rcl}
  x &=& 9.5 \\[6pt]
  y &=& 9.75 \\[2pt]
  \end{array} \hspace{3.5em} [\text{by using G.D.C.}]\end{aligned}
  $$

  Hence the coordinates of D are
$\answer{(9.5,9.75)}$
- $\answer{\mathrm{MD} \approx 5.03}$
- If we sketch the lines $L_1$ and $L_2$, and the points A, B, C, D
and M, we have
  ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/b013bdd6-5c84-45cd-88f4-56ef7bb231a9/images/fe7ba0a5-c700-4399-a915-517dd0ed1fe8/77fb9723b552ee7da7594cc46fb5967dcf76c511.svg)


  Using the area of a rhombus formula, we find

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{11.8em} A &= \dfrac{1}{2}[\mathrm{AC}\times\mathrm{BD}] \\[6pt]
  &\approx \dfrac{1}{2}[13.4][2(5.03)] \hspace{3em} [\text{since $\mathrm{BD} = 2\mathrm{MD}$}] \\[12pt]
  &\answer{\approx 67.4 \text{ unit}^2}\end{aligned}
  $$
